Cyclic carbonates are key compounds with high boiling point, low toxicity, good solubility and biodegradability, exhibiting wide applications. The direct synthesis of cyclic carbonates from cheap olefin and CO2 is a green reaction process, without the separation of intermediate products. Starting from three different organic reaction pathways: auto oxidative carboxylation, assisted oxidative carboxylation, and oxybromination carboxylation, this review covers the catalysts commonly used in reaction processes and the research progress of catalytic mechanism. These catalysts mainly included metal complexes, metal oxides, supported metals, metal-organic frameworks, ionic liquids and molecular sieves. Finally, in order to further improve the efficiency of one-pot oxidative carboxylation reaction, the inspirations for design of catalysts and the optimization of reaction conditions are prospected. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Olefins Carbon dioxide Cyclic carbonates One-pot Oxidative carboxylation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 is the primary greenhouse gas in the atmosphere. With the industrial development, its emissions have been increasing annually, leading to adverse impacts on global climate [1]. Among various methods to reduce CO2 concentration, the catalytic conversion of CO2 into high-value chemical products is receiving considerable attention as a viable solution [2]. This approach not only reduces the content of CO2, but also utilizes it as a plentiful, low-cost, non-toxic, and renewable C1 resource [3]. Among the numerous chemicals transformed by CO2 conversion, five-membered cyclic carbonates (CCs) have been used in industrial fields widely. For example, CCs can be used as synthetic intermediates of polymers, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, and environmentally friendly solvents. The synthesis of CCs through cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides is one of the effective approaches in current research [4]. However, epoxides as substrate are in turn synthesized by the oxidation of olefins in industry, and the complex synthesis process always produces many pollutants and high costs [5]. Therefore, the direct synthesis of CCs from olefins, so called ‘oxidative carboxylation’ can avoid the separation and purification process of intermediate products. In addition, compared with epoxides, olefins are raw materials with less toxicity and cost, leading to a simpler and cheaper way to producing CCs. During 1962–1989, several patents elucidated the industrial application value of methods bypassing epoxides and directly preparing CCs via olefins carboxylation reactions and Yuan et al. [6] summarized these patents. Subsequently, plenty researches were studied on the one-pot reaction, and up to now, the pathways for direct conversion of olefins to CCs were summarized in three categories (Fig. 1 ). Firstly, auto oxidative carboxylation reaction (AuOC, Fig. 1a) could occur in which the substrates (olefins and CO2), oxidant, catalyst and cocatalyst were added to the reactor at one time from the reaction beginning. This pathway includes two reactions, epoxidation of olefins and cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. Thus, the corresponding catalysts should meet the requirements of active sites simultaneously for both above reactions. During the reaction, the conditions were maintained throughout, and CCs were directly synthesized in one pot. Secondly, assisted oxidative carboxylation reaction (AsOC, Fig. 1b) involves sequential epoxidation of olefins and cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. Initially, olefins and catalyst-1 were introduced into the reactor to synthesize intermediate epoxides under conditions conducive to epoxidation. After the end of epoxidation, the catalyst-2 and CO2 for carboxylation were added, and reaction conditions were adjusted to facilitate cycloaddition, thus the CCs were prepared in two sequential steps. The third pathway was oxybromination-carboxylation (OBC, Fig. 1c). During this approach, olefins underwent oxybromination to yield bromohydrin intermediates, and subsequently, the obtained bromohydrin reacted with CO2 through carboxylation to produce CCs. Due to the chemical stability of CO2 molecules, the occurrence of the above several reactions often requires the participation of catalysts [7]. To this end, researchers have developed lots of catalytic systems for the oxidative carboxylation of alkenes into CCs, including metal catalysts, such as metal complexes, metal oxides, metal-organic frameworks, etc. It also includes some non-metallic catalysts, such as ionic liquids, etc. Therefore, this review summarized the catalysts used in the three above reaction pathways mainly, and analyzed their catalytic activities in the catalytic oxidative carboxylation of olefin under optimal reaction conditions. Through mechanism studies, the structural-activity relationship among them was explored, and the action mechanism of each active site was revealed. 2 Auto oxidative carboxylation reaction 2.1 Metal complex catalysis Metal complexes were the earliest catalysts used on oxidative carboxylation of olefins to CCs. Common metal complexes included metal porphyrin complexes, metal salen complexes and metal schiff base complexes. As early as 1987, Italian researchers Aresta and Quaranta [8] first investigated the direct oxidative carboxylation of olefins to CCs. On the conditions of 40 °C and O2/CO2 mixed atmosphere (0.5 bar for each component), using Rhodium complexes RhClP3 (P = Pet2Ph, PEtPh2) and RhClL2 (L2 = diphos, dipy) as catalysts, the reaction of styrene with CO2 yielded target product styrene carbonates (SC) with yields ranging from 21 % to 30 %. Meanwhile, they also observed that the rate of styrene reacting with CO2 to generate SC was higher compared to the rate of styrene oxide (SO) reacting with CO2 to produce SC. This discovering confirmed that the formation of SO was not a necessary step in the synthesis of SC. Subsequently, the team's research in 1992 [9] demonstrated that during the reaction catalyzed by Rhodium complexes, CO2 played a crucial role in the epoxidation of olefins. It could not only increase the conversion of styrene, but also suppress the formation of benzaldehyde during the epoxidation process, thereby enhancing the selectivity of SC. In the AuOC reaction catalyzed by metal complexes, besides the influence of CO2 as mentioned above, the solvents also represented one of the crucial factors affecting the yield of target product. Jing et al. [10] employed a combination catalyst consisting of dioxo(tetraphenylporphyrinato) ruthenium(VI) [Ru(TPP)(O)2] and quaternary onium salt (tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI)/tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB)) for the AuOC of olefins, O2 and CO2 under ambient temperature and low-pressure conditions. Using TBAI as cocatalyst, the reaction conditions were set at 30 °C, 0.5 MPa O2 and 1.1 MPa CO2. When ethanol was chosen as solvent, the highest yield of SC reached 89 %. Using dichloromethane (DCM) or tetrahydrofuran (THF) solvent, the yields of SC were 79 % and 15 %, respectively. However, under solvent-free conditions, the SC yield was only 20 %. Studies on mechanism (Fig. 2 ) indicated that at the beginning of reaction, oxygen atoms in [Ru(TPP)(O)2] transferred to the olefin, forming epoxide intermediate. Unlike traditional AuOC mechanism, halide ions were not utilized as nucleophilic reagents during the reaction. Instead, they played a role in activating CO2. The activated CO2 attacked epoxide intermediates, causing the ring opening of epoxide and the insertion of CO2 completed. Then, the intramolecular cyclization occurred, resulting in the formation of CCs and the regeneration of metal porphyrins. Subsequently, the metal porphyrin immediately reacted with oxygen and olefin to form intermediate. This intermediate was attacked by activated C atom, resulting in the generation of another target compound molecule, thereby regenerating the oxo-metalloporphyrin catalyst and completing the catalytic cycle. It was the first research toward the formation of SC with 100 % selectivity at ambient temperature under low pressure. Since manganese (Mn) and iron (Fe) have the versatile valence, they can form important intermediates in epoxidation reactions. Taking Mn as an example, Mn(III) can play important role for epoxidation, since oxo=Mn(V) species could generate in situ through oxidation, which would transfer O to olefins during reaction [11,12]. Hu et al. [11] studied the catalytic mechanism of Mn sites in epoxidation reaction. As shown in Fig. 3 , Mn(II) was initially oxidized to Mn(III), subsequently, Mn(III) further reacted with H2O2 to form O=Mn(V) species. The high-valent intermediates could undergo oxygen atom transfer and revert back to Mn(III) or Mn(II), accompanied by the epoxidation of olefins to form epoxides. Therefore, on the view of catalyst design for AuOC reaction, Mn can be introduced as active sites. Ghosh et al. [13] synthesized a novel Mn(III) complex with amido-amine ligands. Using tert‑butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst, the yield of SC was 43 % under the conditions of 1.7 MPa CO2, 100 °C and 6 h. Mechanistic proposal was shown in Fig. 4 , the catalyst reacted with TBHP, and O atom in TBHP was transferred to obtain metal-oxo species [14]. Firstly, olefins coordinated to the active metal-oxo species to form epoxides. The Br− in TBAB attacked epoxides to open their rings, and then CO2 inserted the opened rings to form alkoxide intermediates. The intramolecular cyclization of alkoxide intermediates obtained CCs, and the Mn(III) complex was also regenerated. This study explained the important role of obtained Mn(V)=O species transformed from Mn(III) in the AuOC of manganese complexes. It served as a valuable strategy for the development of future catalysts containing Mn. Besides Mn-complexes, Singh G. et al. [15] in 2023 developed an Fe(III)-anchored porphyrin-based covalent organic framework (COF), Fe(III)@P-COF. Using styrene and CO2 as substrates, iodosobenzene (PhIO, 1.5 mmol) as oxidant, TBAB (0.3 mmol) as cocatalyst and CH2Cl2 (2 mL) as solvent, the reaction was conducted under the conditions of 80 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2 and 24 h. The conversion of styrene was ≥99 %, and the selectivity of SC was 99 %. The reaction mechanism of AuOC catalyzed by Fe(III)@P-COF was shown in Fig. 5 . In the presence of PhIO, Fe(III) catalyzed the epoxidation of olefin to SO. Under the attack of Br− from TBAB, SO underwent the ring-opening step and yielded bromo‑alkoxide. Subsequently, CO2 was inserted into metal-alkoxide intermediates, and then intramolecular ring closure reaction occurred to produce SC, and Fe(III)@P-COF was also regenerated. The whole process achieved AuOC reaction under atmospheric pressure, which was an advance for the study of reaction under mild conditions. In the same year, Nagaraja et al. [16] from the same team reported another Fe-porphyrin catalyst, Fe(III)-centered porphyrin-based bifunctional ionic porous organic polymers (Fe-IPOP1/2) for AuOC. Using styrene as substrate, PhIO as oxidant, DCM as solvent, the reaction was carried out at the conditions of 80 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2 and 24 h. The styrene conversion reached 99 % with 96 % yield of SC. This work showed the mechanism of oxophilic Fe sites in ionic Fe-porphyrin polymer and nucleophilic Br− during the direct synthesis of CCs by AuOC. 2.2 Metal oxide catalysis Aresta et al. [17] tested the performance of various metal oxides, including Group 1 and 2 or transition-metal oxides, for the AuOC reaction of olefins. Among the metal oxide catalysts, Nb2O5 exhibited high catalytic activity under the conditions of 120 °C and 5 h, resulting in 27 % styrene conversion and 17 % SC yield. In addition, they conducted kinetic analysis for this reaction, which showed that under the same conditions and the same catalyst, the formation rate of CCs from one-step reaction of olefins and CO2 O2 was faster than that from cycloaddition of epoxide and CO2. The result is possibly because the ring-opening step of epoxides was avoided during AuOC of olefins, which might be the limiting step from thermodynamic and kinetic point of view. Ma et al. [18] prepared CeO2 nanorods (NR-CeO2) containing FLPs (interfacial frustrated Lewis pairs, two adjacent Ce3+…O2−). On the AuOC of styrene, using TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as initiator under the conditions of 80 °C, 2.0 MPa CO2 and 24 h, NR-CeO2 presented 94 % styrene conversion and 94 % SC yield. The proposed mechanism (Fig. 6 ) showed that Ce3+ in FLPs electrophilically activated two O atoms in CO2, O2− nucleophilically activated C in CO2, and Ce3+ could also activate peroxides to catalyze olefins to form epoxides intermediates. Eventually, the activated CO2 was electrophilically attacked by the obtained epoxides and yielding the target product CCs in situ. It was found that defective CeO2 could not only provide effective CO2 activation for cycloaddition by providing more FLP sites, but also weaken the adsorption of in situ epoxides to inhibit the occurrence of side reaction hydrolysis. 2.3 Supported metals catalysis The outer d orbital electrons of precious metals were easy to covalently bond with oxygen atoms to form oxygen-containing donors, which were used to catalyze various oxidation reactions [19]. In particular, the supported Au catalyst showed good catalytic performance on the epoxidation of olefins [20]. Sun et al. [21] combined SiO2-supported Au catalyst with ZnBr2/TBAB (Au/SiO2-ZnBr2/TBAB) to synthesize SC from styrene and CO2 by AuOC. Au/SiO2 mainly catalyzed the epoxidation of styrene, while ZnBr2/TBAB together catalyzed the cycloaddition of CO2 and obtained SO, resulting in good SC yield under mild reaction conditions (80 °C, 1.0 MPa CO2 and 4 h). Catalytic results showed that different oxidants used in the reaction affected significantly for styrene conversion and SC yield. Under the same conditions, using anhydrous TBHP as oxidant, styrene conversion was 90 % with 36 % SC yield, while using aqueous TBHP, SC yield reduced to 21 %, which was attributed to the hydrolysis of epoxide to phenyl glycol [22]. When cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) was used as oxidant, SC yield reached 45 %. By comparing the effect of CO2 pressure on conversion of styrene and SO under the same conditions, they found that the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides was much faster than the epoxidation of styrene, and concluded that epoxidation reaction was the rate-determining step of AuOC of styrene to SC. Moreover, in the absence of CO2, the epoxidation of styrene resulted in 40 % SO yield, which was similar to SC yield from AuOC of styrene by using the same catalyst (37 %). This result indicated that the epoxidation performance of the catalyst largely determined the efficiency of one-pot oxidative carboxylation of SC. In conclusion, synthesizing catalysts with active sites for epoxidation could lead to the development of more efficient AuOC catalyst system. This provided crucial guidance for the design of catalysts for AuOC reaction of olefins. Subsequently, Sun group [23] further developed the [Au/Fe(OH)3]-ZnBr2/TBAB combination catalysts. Under the conditions of 80 °C, 4.0 MPa CO2 and 10 h, using TBHP as oxidant, SC yield reached to 53 % with 60 % selectivity. The results showed that the synergistic effect of Au3+ and Fe(OH)3 supporter was the key for epoxidation of styrene. In order to reduce cost, it was expected to use non-precious metals instead of precious metals to develop metal-supported catalysts for AuOC of olefins. Recently, Chen et al. [24] developed a carbon-based catalyst with atomically dispersed dual Fe-Al sites (ADD-Fe-Al) for AuOC reaction. Using TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst, ADD-Fe-Al performed 97 % styrene conversion and 91 % SC selectivity under the condition of 0.5 MPa CO2 and 80 °C. When AD-Al or AD-Fe was used alone, the styrene conversion and SC yield were lower than those of ADD-Fe-Al, indicating the roles of dual metal sites in improving the catalytic performance. Kinetic experiments informed that atomically dispersed Fe as oxidative sites catalyzed the epoxidation of olefins and Al as Lewis acid sites catalyzed the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides. Simultaneously, cycloaddition process accelerated the consumption of epoxides, promoting the equilibrium shift of olefin epoxidation over Fe catalytic sites, thus enhancing the selectivity of epoxidation products. The synergistic effect of Fe/Al dual active sites resulted in good performance of ADD-Fe-Al for AuOC of olefins. This work presented a new strategy for the preparation and coordination environment control of multifunctional single-atom catalysts, and provided a method for design of supported metal catalysts for AuOC of olefins. 2.4 MOFs catalysis Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) possess porous structure, showing good adsorption capacity to CO2. Therefore, MOFs have been applied to catalytic conversion of CO2. For example, Cr-MIL-101 not only performed efficiently for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides to CCs, [25] but also exhibited good catalytic activity on epoxidation of olefins with TBHP as oxidant [26]. Therefore, as early as 2013, Balzhinimaev et al. [27] first evaluated the catalytic performance of Cr-MIL-101 for the AuOC of styrene. With CH2Cl2 as solvent, at the conditions of 25 °C, 0.8 MPa CO2 and 5 h, the styrene conversion was only 39 % and the selectivity of SC was only 19 %. They found that the poor performance was assigned to excessive oxidation to form byproduct benzaldehyde with 79 % selectivity. Two years later, Duan et al. [28] further improved the efficiency of MOFs in catalyzing AuOC reaction. They combined Keggin-type [ZnW12O40]6− anions, Zn2+, NH2-functionalized bridging links, NH2-bipyridine (NH2-BPY) and asymmetric organocatalytic groups, pyrrolidine-2-yl-imidazole (PYI) to synthesize two POMOFs: ZnW-PYI1 and ZnW-PYI2. Using ZnW-PYI1 as catalyst, the AuOC reaction was carried out with styrene as substrate, TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst at 50 °C and 0.5 MPa CO2 for 96 h. The conversion of styrene was 92 % and the selectivity for SC was 80 %. The catalytic mechanism was shown in Fig. 7 . Polyoxometalate acted as active sites for epoxidation and worked with the oxidant TBHP to oxidize styrene to SO. In the subsequent cycloaddition reaction, the Zn centers acted as Lewis acidic sites to activate epoxides, which were then attacked by the nucleophile TBAB, completing the ring-opening. The NH2 groups of BPY then activated CO2, allowing it to smoothly insert into the ring-opening intermediates and complete the cycloaddition reaction. Gándara et al. [29] synthesized three new lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) by solvothermal method, namely MOF-590, −591 and −592 with tetratopic linkers, benzoimidephenanthroline tetracarboxylic acid (H4BIPA-TC). The unique three-dimensional framework enabled the three MOFs to possess good CO2 adsorption property. For AuOC of styrene, MOF-590 performed efficient catalysis under solvent-free and mild conditions of 80 °C, 1 atm CO2 and 10 h. Using TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst, the styrene conversion could reach 96 %, and selectivity and yield for SC were 95 % and 91 %, respectively. The mechanism of the AuOC reaction catalyzed by MOF-590 was shown in the Fig. 8 . Firstly, TBHP oxidized Nd3+ clusters to produce Nd4+-peroxy species. Nd4+-peroxy species then released t-butoxy radicals, while MOF-590 was regenerated. t-Butoxy radicals reacted with styrene to form t-butoxperoxy intermediates, which further underwent oxygen transfer to form SO, completing the epoxidation of styrene. The O atoms of SO were first activated by the Nd units, then epoxide coordination molecules were attacked by Br− as nucleophile, and the rings were opened to form the metal-coordinated bromoalkoxide. Next, CO2 inserted into the Nd-O bond, forming metal-carbonate intermediates. Finally, the ring-closing of metal-carbonate intermediates occurred, resulting in the formation of the target product SC. Gándara et al. [30] also synthesized a novel series of two zirconium- and one indium-based MOFs, namely MOF-892, MOF-893, and MOF-894, constructed from the hexatopic linker, 1′,2′,3′,4′,5′,6′-hexakis (4-carboxyphenyl) benzene. All the three MOFs served as highly efficient catalysts for cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides, particularly MOF-892. Meanwhile, MOF-892 also exhibited high activity in AuOC of olefins to CCs. Using TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst, the reaction proceeded at 80 °C and 1 atm of CO2 for 9 h, MOF-892 presented 100 % styrene with 80 % SC selectivity. In 2020, Ahn et al. [2] reported an imidazolium bromide IL-functionalized metalloporphyrin ImBr-MOF-545(Mn) through a post-synthetic method. ImBr-MOF-545(Mn) catalyst was applied for the AuOC reaction of olefins. Using O2 (0.5 MPa) and isobutyraldehyde (IBA) as oxidant, under the conditions of 60 °C, 0.5 MPa CO2 and 10 h, ImBr-MOF-545(Mn) presented 99 % conversion of styrene with 95 % selectivity to SC. Meanwhile, the catalysts could be reused for 5 times. They also proposed a plausible mechanism for the AuOC reaction. The catalytic result by using butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) as a free radical inhibitor indicated that the reaction epoxidation was through free radical pathway. On one hand, the highly active acylperoxy radical produced from ImBr-MOF-545(Mn), IBA and O2, could attack olefins to yield epoxides. On the other hand, oxo-Mn(IV) species complex was formed by acylperoxy radical reacting with Mn(II), and then the O atom transferred to olefins to yield epoxides. Through solvothermal methods. Iglesias et al. [31] synthesized two new isoreticular nitrogen-rich naphthalene cobalt-MOFs, named Co-NDTz and Co-NDPhTz. The both Co-MOFs not only performed good CO2 adsorption capacity, but also exhibited highly efficient activity in AuOC of olefins with CO2. With TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst, the styrene conversion was 100 % with 78 % SC yield under the conditions of 0.3 MPa CO2 and 110 °C for 16 h. The catalytic mechanism was shown in Fig. 9 . First, TBHP oxidized unsaturated Co(II) to form Co(III)-peroxy species. Co(III)-peroxy species then released t-butoxy radicals, while Co(II) sites were regenerated. These radicals reacted with styrene to form t-butoxperoxy derivates, which further underwent oxygen transfer to obtain SO, completing the epoxidation step. Subsequently, the epoxides were activated by coordination to Co active centers. The β-C atoms in epoxides were then attacked by Br− to open the ring, then CO2 inserted into the Co-oxygen bond to form cobalt-carbonate intermediates. CCs were obtained by intramolecular ring-closing step, accompanied by regeneration of Co-MOF and cocatalyst. Duan et al. [32] employed reflux method to prepare two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets (NS) Ni-based MOF, Ni-BDCNS (BDC = 1,4- dicarboxybenzene). For the AuOC reaction of olefins with CO2, Ni-BDCNS exhibited excellent activity under mild conditions (80 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2, 12 h), the styrene conversion and SC yield could reach 95 % and 87 %. The catalytic mechanism of AuOC was shown in Fig. 10 . In epoxidation step, Ni-BDCNS reacted with TBHP to form Ni(III)-peroxy species and released peroxide radicals. The radicals acted as electrophile to attract styrene and form t-butoxoperoxy intermediates, and t-butoxoperoxy further oxidized styrene. In cycloaddition reaction, SO was activated by interaction with unsaturated Ni(II) as Lewis acid sites, and then Br− as nucleophile from TBAB attacked the C atom with less hinder of SO to open the ring, thus yielding metal-coordinated bromoalkoxide. Its O anions then attacked the introduced CO2, forming the alkyl carbonate anion, which then reacted with the β-carbon of the ring-opened epoxides. Finally, after ring-closing step occurred, the CC was finally released, and the Ni-BDCNS catalyst and TBAB cocatalyst were also regenerated for the next cycle. Next year, Yu et al. [33] prepared another two-dimensional MOF named Zr-BTB/PA-Co (BTB=1,3,5-Tri(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene, PA = 4-picolinic acid). It also exhibited highly efficiency for auto one-step oxidative carboxylation of olefins. Under the conditions of 80 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2 and 12 h, the styrene conversion was 94 % with 93 % SC yield. The catalytic mechanism was similar to that of above NiBDC-nanosheet. The above two reports achieved AuOC of olefins efficiently, providing an avenue for the design of 2D MOF catalysts for the direct synthesis of CCs. Besides the above nanosheets catalysts, Tian et al. [34] designed and synthesized a hierarchical MOF composite IL-Au@UiO-66-NH2/CMC(carboxymethylcellulose), integrating acid (Zr4+), base (ionic liquid (IL)) and metal sites (Au nanoparticles), to catalyze AuOC of olefins without any cocatalyst. The experimental results showed that with TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst, IL-Au0.21 wt%@UiO-66-NH2/CMC provided 91 % styrene conversion and 81 % selectivity SC at conditions of 0.1 MPa CO2, 80 °C and 24 h. During the experiment, it was found that the catalytic efficiency of the catalyst would be reduced in the presence of DMF (N, N-dimethylformamide) and other solvents, because the solvent molecules directly or indirectly affected the energetics of adsorbents, transition states and intermediates through the interaction of solid-liquid interface. The latest research on MOFs catalyzed AuOC was reported by Sun et al. [35] They synthesized a series of bimetallic MnZn-MOF-74 with different ratios of Mn and Zn. They found that the different Zn amount in MnZn-MOF-74 could regulated the valance state distributions of Mn. Among the three bimetallic MOFs, Mn99.3Zn0.7 −MOF-74 possessed high ratio of active Mn(III). MnZn-MOF-74 were used on the epoxidation of olefins, and the cycloaddition of epoxides and CO2, respectively, revealing Mn(III) as the main oxidative centers and Zn as main acid centers. On AuOC reaction of styrene, using aqueous TBHP as oxidant and TBAB as cocatalyst, Mn99.3Zn0.7 −MOF-74 provided 92 % conversion of styrene with 60 % selectivity of SC under the conditions of 90 °C, 1.0 MPa CO2 and 4 h. They also studied on the mechanism (Fig. 11 ) through control experiment with BHT, and presented two pathways during epoxidation of olefins, metal-peroxide pathway-1 and free radical pathway-2. In pathway-1, Mn(II/III) were oxidized by TBHP to produced Mn(IV/V = O). In pathway-2, tBuOO∙ radicals were formed by Mn(III) and TBHP. Thus, Mn(IV/V = O) and tBuOO∙ radicals resulted in the transferring of O atoms to olefins to yield epoxides intermediate. Then, Mn and Zn as Lewis acid sites cooperated with O2− Lewis base sites together to achieve the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides. 2.5 Molecular sieve catalysis In the early stage, the active sites for epoxidation and cycloaddition were introduced into the modified molecular sieve by means of doping and loading, which was used as effective single catalysts for oxidative carboxylation of olefins. Yuan et al. [36] used two-step condensation method of dicyandiamide to prepare well-dispersed g-C3N4 nanophase in SBA-15 mesochannels. Among different transition metal ions doped into the g-C3N4 nanophase, Fe3+doped g-C3N4/SBA-15 was an efficient catalyst for the AuOC of olefins. With O2 as oxidant, the yield of CCs was 25 % under the conditions of 150 °C, 3.0 MPa CO2 and 5 h. There was no significant decrease in catalyst activity after 5 conductive cycles, and no obvious metal leaching was observed during the reactions. Titanosilicate molecular sieves were common selective oxidation catalyst, [37,38] especially for the epoxidation of olefins [39–41]. Ayupov et al. [42] employed mesoporous titanium-silicate molecular sieves in combination with TBAB as catalyst system and TBHP as oxidant for AuOC reaction of styrene and 4-methylstyrene, under mild and solvent-free conditions (50∼70 °C, 0.8 MPa CO2 and 48 h). Styrene and 4-methylstyrene conversion were 92 % and 99 %, respectively, with corresponding selectivity of CCs reaching approximately 70 %. Catalytic results indicated that the state of titanium in molecular sieve influenced its catalytic activity. Compared to isolated Ti atoms, di(oligo) meric titanium species were more suitable as active centers for the reaction. The mesoporous titanium-silicate catalyst Ti-MMM-E exhibited the highest activity and selectivity among titanium catalysts. Under solvent-free conditions, the active metal ions did not leach into the solution, and even after seven conductive times, the catalyst structure and the state of titanium active centers remained unchanged. And it was suggested that Br− played role in epoxidation of olefins, and CO2 fixation might occur where CO2 was inserted directly into an intermediate formed during the transfer of oxygen atoms. However, kinetic and spectral studies are needed to further understand and verify this mechanism. Li et al. [43] synthesized walnut-like zeolite LZ-276 by hydrothermal method, and applied it to the AuOC reaction of styrene to synthesize SC. Under the conditions of 0.5 MPa CO2 and 140 °C for 10 h, LZ-276 provided 77 % SC yield. The reaction mechanism was shown in Fig. 12 . Firstly, I − was oxidized by TBHP to OI−, then iodohydrin was formed by iodination of styrene in the presence of little H2O, which was then dehydroiodinated under alkaline condition to obtain SO intermediates. Subsequently, nucleophilic I − collaborated with Al atoms in the zeolite framework to attack the β-C atom of SO, which experienced relatively less steric hindrance, resulting in ring opening and formation of oxygen anion intermediates. CO2 molecules were activated by silicon atoms in zeolite structure and inserted into oxyanion intermediates to form alkyl carbonates. Finally, upon departure of I −, the alkyl carbonates underwent cyclization to form the target product SC. 2.6 Ionic liquids catalysis Hu et al. [44] employed imidazolium hydrogen carbonate ionic liquids (ILs) [CnCmIm] [HCO3] for AuOC of olefins and CO2 to CCs. Under the conditions of 65 °C, 2.0 MPa CO2 and 30 h, the conversion of styrene was 91 % and selectivity of SC was 82 %. As shown in Fig. 13 , [CnCmIm] [HCO3] as bifunctional catalysts could dissociate HCO3 − and spontaneously convert into carbene-CO2 adducts, then HCO4 − and carbene-CO2 could respectively catalyze epoxidation of olefin and CO2 cycloaddition, finishing the AuOC reaction to CCs. This catalytic reaction conducted under mild conditions and without the use of any solvent. Furthermore, the catalyst retained its activity even after four cycles, exhibiting good potential for direct synthesis of CCs. The application of supported ILs could solve the separation and recovery problem faced by homogeneous ILs during reaction. Therefore, Hu et al. [45] prepared a series of [Im] [HCO3]@SBA-15 catalysts by using anion exchange and solvent-free mehcanochemical grafting strategies. For the direct synthesis of CCs from olefins and CO2. Under the conditions of 80 °C and 1.0 MPa CO2 for 28 h, the conversion of styrene was 95 % and SC yield was 82 %. The possible mechanism of AuOC catalyzed by [Im] [HCO3]@SBA-15 was shown in Fig. 14 . HCO3 − reacted with TBHP to form peroxymonocarbonate species (HCO4 −) and t-butanol, HCO4 − transferred the activated O atoms to styrene to yield SO, and HCO3 − was regenerated to complete the first epoxidation reaction. Carbene-CO2 adducts were formed in two pathways, the one was by N(CH3)2- [Im] [HCO3]@SBA-15 to spontaneously remove one molecule H2O, and the other one was by fixing CO2 on the catalyst. Carbene-CO2 adducts acted as nucleophile to attack C atoms with less steric hindrance in SO, leading to ring-opening of SO to form alcohol oxide intermediates. Finally, after CO2 was inserted, SC was generated by cyclization step. Table 1 summarized the AuOC reaction for the conversion of styrene to styrene-carbonate. 3 Assisted oxidative carboxylation reactions Above AuOC involved adding all reagents and catalysts from the outset, and maintaining consistent reaction conditions from the beginning to the end. In fact, epoxidation and cycloaddition were two different reaction processes, which required corresponding reaction conditions and catalyst active sites. However, the mixture in reactor would occur competitive reactions, which could lead to the degradation of reagents and products, as well as catalyst deactivation. Therefore, the concept of assisted oxidative carboxylation (AsOC) was proposed, which emphasized that once the first step was completed, these problems can be circumvented by adding specific reactants or changing reaction condition. Controlling the reaction conditions of the two reaction processes will be also conducive to more efficient conversion of olefins into CCs. 3.1 Metal complex catalysis Hu et al. [46] used molybdenyl acetylacetonate [MoO2(acac)2]-TBAB catalytic system to efficiently convert alkenes and CO2 into CCs through assisted oxidative carboxylation reaction. When [MoO2(acac)2]-TBAB system catalyzed AuOC, the presence of TBAB led to a negative effect on the epoxidation of olefins. It was because that the Br− from excess TBAB could catalyze and decomposition of TBHP and [MoO2(acac)2] to form O2, t-BuOH and MoO2Br2, and then the catalytic system was consumed, leading to a low activity on the AuOC. Thus, the direct synthesis of CCs was conducted by AsOC. Firstly, using [MoO2(acac)2]-TBHP catalyzed the epoxidation of olefins under conditions of 100 °C and 1 h. After the completion of this process, TBAB was added into reactor, and the cycloaddition was proceeded at 140 °C, 3.0 MPa CO2 and 1 h. Finally, the CCs yield could reach 84 %. The mechanism was shown in Fig. 15 . Hydroperoxide was coordinated with the metal centers to form the key intermediate alkylperoxo M-OOR, and olefins were coordinated with alkylperoxom M-OOR to form a ternary transition state, and epoxides were then formed by complexation and oxygen transfer. The coordination of [Bu4N]+ in TBAB with epoxides enhanced the nucleophile attack effect of Br−, thus opening the ring of epoxides, so that the activated CO2 can be easily inserted to form CCs. In 2017, Baj et al. [47] developed an effective one-pot method for the direct synthesis of CCs from CO2 and olefins in the presence of TBHP as oxidant using the system consisting of MoO2(acac)2 and PS-tributylmethylammonium chloride (PS-TBMAC)/ ZnBr2 aqueous solution. Compared with [MoO2(acac)2]/TBAB system mentioned above, when the yields of CCs maintained at 50∼77 %, the conditions of this system were more moderate, both steps were conducted at 100 °C with only 0.9 MPa CO2 during the cycloaddition step. In addition, the immobilized PS-TBMAC catalyst was easily filtered and separated from the reaction mixture, which improved recyclability of the catalyst. Recently, Launay et al. [48] developed Salophen-Me2NCr/TBAB catalytic systems for AsOC of styrene. They compared the effect of AuOC and AsOC approaches for direct synthesis of CCs. First, they conducted the oxidative carboxylation of styrene with O2 and CO2 using Salophen-tBu-Cr complexes and TBAB in the presence of IBA, through AuOC approach with identical temperature and pressure parameters. The yield of SC could only reach 14 % after 24 h. Then, they set the conditions in two steps. In the first step, IBA was added to reactor at 80 °C and 0.4 MPa O2 for 3 h for epoxidation of styrene. In the second step of cycloaddition reaction, O2 was separated first, and then TBAB and Salophen-Me2NCr were added to the reactor. Under the conditions of 80 °C and 1.1 MPa CO2 for 20 h, the SC yield could be improved to 31 %. 3.2 Supported metal catalysis Sun et al. [49] reported a novel and convenient synthetic route for SC from styrene and CO2 over nano-gold catalyst supported R201 resin. Because CO2 had a negative effect on the epoxidation reaction by Au/R201 catalyst, the styrene conversion obtained by AuOC was very low and almost no SC was produced. However, in the AsOC approach, the styrene conversion rate was 98 % and the SC yield increased to 51 %. In this AsOC approach (Fig. 16 ), CO2 acted as both reagent and solvent, thus the use of additional organic solvents could be avoided. Hutchings et al. [50] used the supported gold catalyst (Au/SiO2) for the epoxidation reaction, and catalyzed the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 through the combination of TBAB and ZnBr2, and finally achieved AsOC reaction. Using 1-decene as the substrate and O2 as oxidant, epoxidation reaction was carried out at 90 °C for 24 h, and then continued at 2.0 MPa CO2 for 4 h. The final yield of 1,2-decylene carbonate was 24 %. Catalytic results showed that selectivity of epoxide was significantly reduced in the presence of TBAB and ZnBr2. Further analysis of these results indicated that in presence of TBAB, organic polymer-like layer was formed on the catalyst surface, and the catalyst morphology changed after the addition of ZnBr2. 3.3 MOFs catalysis Li et al. [51] synthesized a catalyst Cu3(μ3-OH)2(4,4′-BPY) (MoO4)2 (CuMo-BPY, BPY=4,4′-bipyridine) by incorporating a molybdate oxidation catalyst and alkaline μ3-OH tricopper(II) cores into MOF, which was used for AsOC reaction of olefins to CCs. Using TBAB as cocatalyst and TBHP as oxidant, the epoxidation reaction was first carried out at 50 °C. After reaction for 48 h, the temperature remained unchanged, and CO2 was introduced to 0.5 MPa for another 48 h of cycloaddition. The catalytic system could provide the yield of SC up to 90 %, and showed good universality for various olefins on AsOC. The mechanism was shown in Fig. 17 . CuMo-BPY catalyst was first oxidized by TBHP to form peroxide molybdenum intermediates, which acted as electrophilic reagents to attract styrene, thus forming epoxide products. In cycloaddition reaction, basic μ-OH tricopper (II) core in CuMo-BPY fixed and activated CO2. At the same time, the O atoms of epoxides in coordination with Bu4N+ would promote the nucleophilic attack of Br- on C atoms in epoxides, resulting in the ring-opening of epoxides and the generation of oxygen anions. The activated CO2 was then inserted, and through intramolecular ring-closing step, SC was generated. Through ion exchange and impregnation, Yang et al. [52] prepared a multifunctional catalyst Au@ [IM+]/ [MIL-101-SO3 −] by incorporating imidazolyl ILs and gold nanoparticles (Au-NPs) into sulfonic acid grafted MIL-101(Cr). Using TBHP and O2 as oxidants, epoxidation was proceeded at 80 °C. Then, the cycloaddition reaction was carried out using TBAB as cocatalyst under 1.0 MPa CO2. The final results showed that styrene conversion was higher than 99 % and SC yield was 75 %. The mechanism (Fig. 18 ) showed that TBHP was used as an initiator to activate molecular oxygen, enhancing the activity of epoxidation reaction, while Au sites were employed to improve the selectivity of epoxidation reaction. The sulfonic acid group and Cr3+ in MOF acted as acid centers to activate epoxides, together with Br− as nucleophile to achieve the ring-opening of epoxides. Imidazole cations in ILs can activate CO2, allowing it to insert into the intermediates after the opening of the epoxides, and eventually to form SC. 3.4 Molecular sieve catalysis Ratnasamy et al. [53] catalyzed AsOC of olefins in two steps using a combination catalyst of titanosilicate molecular sieves (TS-1 or TiMCM-41) and N,N-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP). In epoxidation reaction, 400 mg TS-1 and 1 mL of 50 % aqueous H2O2 (14.7 mmol) were added and the reaction was conducted at 60 °C for 8 h. Then, DMAP dissolved in acetone was added. In the second cycloaddition reaction, the temperature was raised to 120 °C, the CO2 pressure was set to 0.7 MPa, and the reaction continued for another 4 h. When using TiMCM-41 as a catalyst, the epoxidation reaction needed to be maintained for 24 h with TBHP oxidant. The catalytic results showed that the activity on cycloaddition of TiMCM-41 catalytic system was much better than that of TS-1 catalytic system, because TiMCM-41 possessed larger pore structure than TS-1. Large pore channels made it easier for CCs diffused from the active sites of catalyst. Liu et al. [54] synthesized a new catalyst Del-Ti-MWW-N +Bu3Br− by grafting quaternary ammonium halide on a titanosilicate. The catalyst was applied to AsOC of olefins. Using H2O2 oxidant, the epoxidation reaction was conducted at 40 °C for 1 h, followed by the cycloaddition reaction under conditions of 140 °C and 2.0 MPa CO2 for 6 h, the yield of propylene carbonate (PC) reached 48 %. However, byproducts with large molecules size formed at high temperature of 140 °C blocked the pores, which caused the decrease of the BET surface area of the catalyst, significantly weakening the recyclability of the catalyst. 3.5 Other material catalysis Besides the above catalysts, the composite catalysts formed by combining various catalysts through specific methods might possess multiple catalytic functions, which could meet the requirements for AsOC reaction. Gao et al. [55] developed the system of quaternary ammonium heteropolyphosphatotungstate-TBAB as an efficient catalyst for the direct synthesis of PC from CO2 and propylene. First, propylene, oxidant (anhydrous H2O2) and heteropolyphosphatotungstate were added to the reactor, and epoxidation of propylene was proceeded at 75 °C for 3.5 h. Then TBAB and CO2 were added, and cycloaddition was carried out at 140 °C for 4 h. The final PC yield could reach 99 %. The mechanism of the AsOC reaction was shown in Fig. 19 . First, H2O2 oxidized the catalyst to form tungsten peroxide intermediates, which could oxidize the alkenes to epoxides. The water molecules produced in this process promoted the nucleophilic attack of TBAB on the less sterically hinderer C atoms in propylene oxide (PO), causing ring of PO to open. The oxygen anion produced from the open ring attacked CO2 to form CO2-adduct, and then generated PC. Table 2 summarized the AsOC reaction for the conversion of styrene to styrene-carbonate. 4 Oxybromination-carboxylation reaction Apart from the reaction involving epoxidation followed by carboxylation, another oxidative carboxylation reaction of olefins was the initial oxybromination (OB) reaction, forming bromohydrin intermediates, [56,57] followed by insertion of CO2 to yield CCs. Sun et al. [58] first explored this reaction employing TBAB catalyst for the one-pot synthesis of CCs from olefins. Using TBHP as oxidant, styrene was almost completely transformed at 1.0 MPa CO2 and 80 °C for 6 h, and the yield of SC reached 38 %. Through studying the impact of various reaction parameters on the one-pot reaction, it was found that CO2 pressure was the most crucial factor. At lower pressure, increasing CO2 pressure would promote OB of styrene and subsequent cycloaddition reaction. However, at higher CO2 pressures, phase transition led to an increase in reaction volume, and simultaneously high pressure resulted in the formation of oligomers, which was unfavorable for the synthesis of CCs from CO2 and epoxides. The mechanism of this catalyst was shown in Fig. 20 . TBHP catalyzed the oxidation of Br− to generate hypobromite (OBr−). In the presence of water, olefins underwent bromination to form bromohydrins. The base promoted dehydrobromination of the bromohydrin leading to epoxide. Nucleophilic attack by Br− opened the epoxide ring, producing oxyanions intermediates. This intermediate was attacked by CO2 to ultimately yield CCs. The advantages of this reaction system lay in its avoidance of organic solvents and high reaction temperature, which was advantageous from both environmental and energy-saving perspectives. Sun et al. [59] then carried out further research on the OBC reaction in 2006, and found that the anions of halogenated reagents had a significant impact on the reaction. The activity sequence of halogenated reagents containing different anions was as follows: TBAB>TBAI>TBACl (tetrabutylammonium chloride). Although I − possessed stronger nucleophilic property, its reducibility was higher, making it easily consumed by oxidants. Therefore, the catalytic effect of Br− was the most favorable. Through control experiments using NaBr as the catalyst, it was found that Br− showed synergistically interact with the cations of quaternary ammonium salt to catalyze the OBC reaction. Following the same mechanism as the aforementioned study, He et al. [60] reported the catalyst system comprising sodium phosphotungstate/TBAB, for the one-step synthesis of SC from styrene and CO2. In this reaction, H2O2 served as oxidant, with an inorganic base acting as the “CO2-activator”. Under conditions of 50 °C, 2.4 MPa CO2 and 12 h, the yield of SC reached 65 %. Interestingly, they found that by subtly tuning the amount of CO2 and H2O2, the selectivity of SC can be controlled. Hatton et al. [61] developed the N-bromosuccinimide (NBS)/NaHCO3 catalytic system to catalyze the one-pot synthesis of SC from styrene. The optimal condition was that 1 equiv. olefin, 1.2 equiv. NBS, 1.1 equiv. NaHCO3, acetone and H2O stirred at 60 °C for 18 h in the microwave reactor. Under these conditions, the conversion of styrene reached 100 % and SC yield was 86 %. Mechanistic studies (Fig. 21 ) indicated that, initially NBS reacted with olefins to form bromohydrin. Subsequently, under the influence of deprotonating agents such as NaHCO3, bromohydrin directly formed CCs. Alternatively, it could form CCs indirectly via SO intermediates. Using NaHCO3 instead of high-pressure CO2 gas and employing microwave heating instead of conventional heating, thereby avoiding high-temperature and high-pressure conditions, was highly beneficial to the safety and energy efficiency of the reaction operation. He et al. [62] developed a simple, metal-free “one-pot” method for the synthesis of CCs from olefins and CO2 presumably going through OBC reaction (Fig. 22 ). First, bromide anion was readily oxidized to bromine by K2S2O8. Thus, NaBr was used as a halogenating agent to promote the oxybromination of styrene with oxidant K2S2O8, and 2‑bromo-1-phenyl-ethanol was formed at 60 °C for 5 h. Then K2CO3 was added as a “deprotonated reagent”, and the final product SC yield was 79 % after the carboxylation reaction under the conditions of 3.0 MPa CO2, 60 °C and 5 h. In addition to inorganic bases, certain organic bases were also employed as deprotonated reagents, in conjunction with halogenating agents, for the OBC process in preparing CCs. Li et al. [63] developed a highly efficient method to convert alkenes and CO2 into CCs directly in water by using NBS together with 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0] undecenc-7-ene (DBU) in water, or by using Br− together with aqueous H2O2. Under conditions of 60 °C, 1.8 MPa CO2 and 3 h, the yield of CCs can reach 89 %. The experimental results showed that the types of halogenating reagents and oxidants could obviously weaken the catalytic activity. Davies et al. [64] used meta chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA) to catalyze the OBC reaction of 1,2-disubstituted olefins to prepare the corresponding disubstituted CCs. Using DBU as “CO2 activator”, reagents and conditions were as follows: Br3CCO2H, m-CPBA, CH2Cl2, room temperature, 18 h. At the end of OB reaction, the base was added into reactor, and the cycloaddition was conducted at 0 °C for another 2 h. Under these conditions, the yield of target CCs corresponding to allyl benzene reached 84 %. Extensive experiments had revealed that this catalytic system was applicable to the OBC reaction of various olefins. Hatton et al. [65] used NBS/DBU catalysts to design a high-efficiency gas-liquid continuous flow synthesis CC system based on the OBC reaction, which could adjust the reaction conditions in real time to ensure the stable mixing and flow of the reaction phase. The system exhibited high activity to a variety of aliphatic and aromatic alkenes, which can be converted into the corresponding CCs within 40 min. The yield of SC was 79 % after 8 h stable flow. Table 3 summarized the OBC reaction for the conversion of styrene to styrene-carbonate. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Up to now, researches on the one-pot synthesis of CCs from oxidative carboxylation of olefins are still not sufficient. There is still much work to do, which attracts the interest of an increasing number of researchers. The transformation from olefins to epoxides, and then from epoxides to CCs, are often viewed as two separate reaction processes. Finding suitable catalysts that enabled both reactions to occur in the same system, eliminating inhibitory factors, and overcoming the immiscibility of the two reactions, are the focuses of future researches. Additionally, continuously expanding the scope of reaction substrates is also a direction that requires effort in catalyst development. The review started from three organic reactions: auto oxidative carboxylation, assisted oxidative carboxylation, and oxybromination carboxylation reactions. It discussed the common catalysts involved in these reactions and their corresponding catalytic mechanisms. From the perspective of green chemistry, the OBC method was not an ideal choice for oxidative carboxylation due to the need for halogenating reagents and deprotonating agents, which generated lots of by-products. Through the change of conditions, assisted oxidative carboxylation could more accurately control the efficient progress of the two reactions and eliminate the interaction between the two reactions to the maximum extent. For example, the presence of CO2 and active sites for cycloaddition could provide the possible inhibition on epoxidation of olefins. However, this approach is relatively complex. On one hand, the reaction conditions need to be changed. On the other hand, catalyst for cycloaddition should be added after epoxidation ending. These operations might lead to the loss of intermediate products easily. From the reaction process, the advantages of auto oxidative carboxylation are obvious, since the substrates, oxidant and catalysts are added to the reactor from the reaction beginning, and the conditions remain unchanged, making the whole process much simpler, which can also avoid the loss of intermediate products. Using homogeneous catalysts or some heterogeneous systems combined with TBAB as cocatalyst will cause difficulties in separation of the product from the catalytic mixtures and decrease the recyclability of the catalyst [66]. To address these issues, it is necessary to develop single-component heterogeneous catalysts that simultaneously possess multiple active sites for CO2 adsorption, epoxidation and cycloaddition reactions. Generally, oxidative carboxylation reactions require high CO2 pressures. However, high pressure inevitably posed certain safety risks. Therefore, optimizing the reaction conditions to atmospheric pressure (or flue gas conditions) will be a significant advancement for this reaction. TBHP exhibits excellent epoxidation activity, making its application wide. However, it's hazard, flammability and toxicity also cause low atom economy and generate waste. Therefore, alternatives such as O2 and H2O2, which are greener oxidants, can be considered. When using O2 as oxidant, the issue of excessive use of aldehyde initiators should also be considered. The review introduced numerous successful instances for the oxidative carboxylation of olefins and CO2 to CCs, but also some cases where the catalytic results were not as satisfactory. All these provided valuable experiences for subsequent related research. coredata.dc:description: Cyclic carbonates are key compounds with high boiling point, low toxicity, good solubility and biodegradability, exhibiting wide applications. The direct synthesis of cyclic carbonates from cheap olefin and CO2 is a green reaction process, without the separation of intermediate products. Starting from three different organic reaction pathways: auto oxidative carboxylation, assisted oxidative carboxylation, and oxybromination carboxylation, this review covers the catalysts commonly used in reaction processes and the research progress of catalytic mechanism. These catalysts mainly included metal complexes, metal oxides, supported metals, metal-organic frameworks, ionic liquids and molecular sieves. Finally, in order to further improve the efficiency of one-pot oxidative carboxylation reaction, the inspirations for design of catalysts and the optimization of reaction conditions are prospected.
